channel.title: (Non-)Functional Ramblings
channel.description: A blog maintained by some guy that likes functional programming.

item.title: Functional programmers enter a diner…
item.description: A fun, I think, thought experiment to avoid concurrency deadlocks by enforcing a fixed, predefined order for acquiring static sets of MVars.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Human-editor interfaces
item.description: A rambling of thoughts and my experience up till now with text editors.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Can I pet your DAG?
item.description: Haskell's ordered maps are fun tools to have in any arsenal. In this post I give an example on doing dependency resolution quickly using the partially ordered nature of dependency relations, using an extremely contrived example.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: We’re All CHAMPs On The Inside
item.description: HAMT's are cool, Haskell has a ubiquitous one in unordered-containers. But other languages have the even cooler CHAMPs. This post is about optimizing the filter-ish functions in an attempt at a drop-in replacement that uses CHAMPs.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Harder-Coded Newtypes
item.description: Newtypes are generally useful to avoid parameter-blindness, but can be cumbersome if each type has it's own wrapper. I explore the use of TypeData and phantom types in Haskell as an alternative way to improve type safety and reduce developer errors.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Lazy-ing in My Pool
item.description: Laziness is underrated. Here I lay out a lazy initialization strategy for managing a pool of resources. It is beneficial to defer initialization to improve performance in scenarios where not all resources are needed simultaneously.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Better than Revivify
item.description: I lay out my journey of revitalizing my long-neglected website, transitioning to using Hakyll. Including styling with Clay, implementing syntax highlighting with Pygments, using KaTeX for mathematical typesetting, and optimizing font usage.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: What’s in the Name?
item.description: One of the first things functional programmers do is implement a lambda calculus interpreter. This post examines various representation methods, including first-order representations and higher-order abstract syntax (HOAS).
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Roly, Oly, …, Polyvariadic Boogaloo
item.description: I revisit the topic of polyvariadic functions, building on a previous attempt by introducing type families to create a more streamlined implementation.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Roly, Oly, …, Polyvariadic
item.description: This introductory post illustrates the concept of polyvariadic functions, using the example of a function that can sum an arbitrary number of integers or return another function.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem
